note: Seeded from Henderson Y2 teacher simulation feedback. Extended editorially to Y1, Y3-Y5 following the same pedagogical patterns: counting-to-tables, place-value-to-decimals, fractions-to-division, multiplication-to-measurement.

links.rationale: Commutativity of addition (C006) parallels commutativity of multiplication (C010). Henderson: 'Teach as deliberate pair, referencing addition work when reaching multiplication.'
Counting in steps of 2, 3, 5 (D001) is the direct precursor to 2, 5, 10 times table recall (D003). Henderson: 'Within-Year-2 prerequisite missing from graph.'
Understanding tens and ones (place value, D001) allows derivation of number facts: 3+7=10 leads to 30+70=100. Henderson identified this as an implicit cross-domain bridge.
Even numbers are multiples of 2. Henderson: 'Connect deliberately when introducing tables.' Odd/even (D001) reinforces the 2x table (D003).
Arrays are themselves patterns. Henderson: 'Use patterns concept from D001 when introducing arrays in D003.' Recognising patterns (D001) supports understanding of multiplication arrays (D003).
Counting in multiples of 2, 5, 10 (D001) is the foundation for grouping and sharing (D003). Skip counting is the oral rehearsal that makes early multiplicative thinking concrete.
Halving (D003) is dividing by 2, which is finding one half (D004). These are the same operation in different representations: procedural (halving) versus conceptual (fraction).
Counting in multiples of 4 (D001) is the direct oral rehearsal for 4 times table recall (D003). Same pattern as Henderson's Y2 counting-to-tables link.
Counting in multiples of 8 (D001) is the direct oral rehearsal for 8 times table recall (D003). Same pattern as Henderson's Y2 counting-to-tables link.

Secure place value understanding of three-digit numbers (D001) is prerequisite for formal columnar addition (D002). Children must understand hundreds/tens/ones columns before the written method makes sense.

Place value in three-digit numbers (D001) extends rightward to tenths (D004). The curriculum explicitly connects these: one-tenth is the same as dividing by 10, extending the place value column structure.
Scaling problems (D003) directly apply multiplication facts to measurement contexts (D005). Recipes, map scales, and unit conversions are natural contexts for both.
Counting in multiples of 6, 7, 9, 25, 1000 (D001) is the oral rehearsal for all multiplication tables to 12x12 (D003). Extends the Henderson counting-to-tables pattern to Y4.
Place value in four-digit numbers (D001) is prerequisite for formal columnar addition/subtraction of four-digit numbers (D002). Extends the Y3 place-value-to-columns pattern.
Place value in four-digit numbers (D001) extends to hundredths and decimal place value (D004). The positional notation system works identically left and right of the decimal point.
Factor pairs and commutativity (D003) directly enable finding equivalent fractions (D004). Multiplying numerator and denominator by the same factor is the same operation as finding factor pairs.
Short multiplication methods (D003) are directly applied in calculating area of rectilinear shapes (D005). Area = length x width is a concrete context for the abstract multiplication procedure.
Hundredths and decimal place value (D004) enables converting between metric units (D005). The curriculum notes: 'pupils connect decimals to metric measures (e.g. 1.25 km = 1 km and 250 m).'
Numbers to 1,000,000 and their place value (D001) extends to thousandths and 3 decimal places (D004). The columnar place value system works symmetrically in both directions.
Factors, common factors, HCF and LCM (D003) are required for adding fractions with different denominators (D004). Finding the lowest common denominator requires LCM knowledge.
Long multiplication of 4-digit by 2-digit numbers (D003) is applied in calculating volume of cuboids (D005). Volume = L x W x H is three-factor multiplication requiring procedural fluency.
